p: Moringa ( Moringa oleifera Lamarck) belongs to the Moringaceae family and although its origins are the regions of northern India, today it is possible to find it in many geographical areas, especially in the warmer regions of the globe such as tropical and subtropical areas. [ 313]. Moringa represents an important multi-tasking crop [ 314] when considering medicinal and nutritional uses. It is characterized by several bioactive phytochemicals, including beta-carotene, proteins, vitamins and variety of phenolics [ 8, 9, 315]. Many biological and pharmacological activities have been reported for various parts of this plant, especially leaves, fruit, roots, seeds and pods that have shown interesting cardiac and circulatory activities [ 316], or antitumoral activity [ 317], and anti-inflammatory property [ 318]. In addition, antidiabetic [ 319] and hepatoprotective [ 320] activities have been documented.
